statements.text: Public displays of affection (PDA) should be allowed in middle school and high school.
Public displays of affection (PDA) shouldn't be allowed in middle school and high school.
Schools are not appropriate places for PDA.
Schools are appropriate places for PDA.
Children have to learn that certain gestures are not appropriate in every context. Forbidding PDA in schools teaches them this.
Children have to learn that certain gestures are appropriate in every context. Forbidding PDA in schools teaches them this.
Showing one's affection for another seems appropriate in any environment as long as it is not disruptive.
Showing one's affection for another seemses appropriate in any environment as long as it is disruptive.
There are many environments in which showing affection is generally considered inappropriate.
There aren't many environments in which showing affection is generally considered inappropriate.
Limiting the physical behaviour of students helps them understand that different situations call for different sets of acceptable behaviours.
Limiting the physical behaviour of students doesn't help them understand that different situations call for different sets of acceptable behaviours.

Society has an obligation to promote the physical and sexual rights of adolescents in ways that are appropriate to their stage of maturity rather than seeking to impose unnecessary limitations on them (p. 137 [1]).

Society doesn't have an obligation to promote the physical and sexual rights of adolescents in ways that are appropriate to their stage of maturity rather than seeking to impose unnecessary limitations on them (p. 137 [1]).
Situational awareness [2] is crucial to the understanding of what constitutes an acceptable PDA.
Situational awareness [2] isn't crucial to the understanding of what constitutes an acceptable PDA.

The ability to discern appropriate times and places for PDA isn't an essential component of workplace decorum [3] that students need to learn.
Schools should be concerned with establishing the same behaviours that will be expected of students when they graduate and enter the workforce.
Schools shouldn't be concerned with establishing the same behaviours that will be expected of students when they graduate and enter the workforce.
It is unreasonable to expect children to conform to the standards expected of adult professionals.
It isn't unreasonable to expect children to conform to the standards expected of adult professionals.
Students have to learn discipline and rigor at school.
Students don't have to learn discipline and rigor at school.
Having the discipline and self-control to refrain from doing something like PDA, despite wanting to, is an important skill for any upstanding member of society.
Having the discipline and self-control to refrain from doing something like PDA, despite wanting to, isn't an important skill for any upstanding member of society.
Higher degrees of self-control in childhood [4] are associated with greater success later in life.
Higher degrees of self-control in childhood [4] aren't associated with greater success later in life.
Personal empowerment [5] is equally important to student success. Disempowering students from making decisions about their social and romantic lives harms their ability to succeed.
Personal empowerment [5] isn't equally important to student success. Disempowering students from making decisions about their social and romantic lives harms their ability to succeed.

There are growing numbers of people who are unable to show or receive affection [6] from others. Thus, schools that punish PDA contribute to this epidemic and harm society by depriving it of affectionate relationships.

There aren't growing numbers of people who are unable to show or receive affection [6] from others. Thus, schools that punish PDA contribute to this epidemic and harm society by depriving it of affectionate relationships.
The primary objective of school is to educate students. Rigour and discipline are not the only ways to achieve this.
The primary objective of school is to educate students. Rigour and discipline are the only ways to achieve this.
Attempting to impose rigour and discipline too strongly can cause students to rebel.
Attempting to impose rigour and discipline too strongly can't cause students to rebel.
A lack of childhood discipline is associated with numerous problems [7].
A lack of childhood discipline isn't associated with numerous problems [7].
Discipline and PDA are not mutually exclusive. Restricting PDA to an acceptable level is a form of discipline.
Discipline and PDA are mutually exclusive. Restricting PDA to an acceptable level is a form of discipline.

A school that teaches children to be disciplined and restrained to the point of withholding the basic human instinct to show affection toward others is an institution that denies and erases their humanity.

A school that teaches children to be disciplined and restrained to the point of withholding the basic human instinct to show affection toward others isn't an institution that denies and erases their humanity.

Education includes becoming familiar with concepts that are likely to affect everyday life, including showing affection for those you love. By allowing PDA, schools are allowing kids to be better prepared for adult life.

Education doesn't include becoming familiar with concepts that are likely to affect everyday life, including showing affection for those you love. By allowing PDA, schools are allowing kids to be better prepared for adult life.
Displays of affection are commonplace in the real world, and learning to be able to deal with that is valuable for students on trajectory to work and live in that world.
Displays of affection are commonplace in the real world, and learning to be able to deal with that isn't valuable for students on trajectory to work and live in that world.
Witnessing PDA is an everyday occurrence [8] for adolescents in the US.
Witnessing PDA isn't an everyday occurrence [8] for adolescents in the US.
There are many countries [9] where PDA are considered completely inappropriate.
There aren't many countries [9] where PDA are considered completely inappropriate.
Many European cultures are incredibly accepting [10] of PDA.
Many European cultures aren't incredibly accepting [10] of PDA.
PDA often occur in many films and TV series [11].
PDA often don't occur in many films and TV series [11].
PDA is also considered inappropriate in many workplaces as well. Since a student's job is to learn, limiting PDA in schools helps them understand how to act in a workplace as well.
PDA isn't also considered inappropriate in many workplaces as well. Since a student's job is to learn, limiting PDA in schools helps them understand how to act in a workplace as well.

Adult life requires an understanding that some actions are not appropriate in given contexts. It is valuable for students to learn the difference between the educational environment in a classroom and the time in-between and after classes.

Adult life requireses an understanding that some actions are appropriate in given contexts. It is valuable for students to learn the difference between the educational environment in a classroom and the time in-between and after classes.
This includes learning how to set, as well as follow, boundaries. Disallowing PDA is an excellent way of teaching this.
This doesn't include learning how to set, as well as follow, boundaries. Disallowing PDA is an excellent way of teaching this.

Maintaining a healthy relationship is an important life skill. Since some students don't get to see their significant other outside of school, they should have an opportunity to learn this skill within school.

Maintaining a healthy relationship is an important life skill. Since some students do get to see their significant other outside of school, they should have an opportunity to learn this skill within school.
It is not the school's responsibility to worry about the extracurricular relationships and behaviours of students.

School isn't the primary social environment for middle and high school students.

Many school policies [12] don't support the position that displays of affection have no place in school.

Many school policies, such as the popular zero-tolerance [13] approach to bullying, haven't been recognised as being short-sighted and unreasonable.

Certain student behaviours can be accepted under any circumstances whatsoever.
If a school board determines that PDA between students are not appropriate, then allowing exceptions to the rule will undermine the authority of the board and the staff.
If a school board determines that PDA between students are appropriate, then allowing exceptions to the rule will undermine the authority of the board and the staff.
Making exceptions to established rules can create uncertainty, jealousy and discontent [15] amongst students.
Not Making exceptions to established rules can create uncertainty, jealousy and discontent [15] amongst students.
Treating all students and situations equally is not always fair. Failing to address students and situations individually does not support student equity.
Treating all students and situations equally is always fair. Failing to address students and situations individually does not support student equity.
This is not a black and white issue. There are types of PDA that would be appropriate in school and types that would not.
This is a black and white issue. There are types of PDA that would be appropriate in school and types that would not.
Having a loose, blanket ban on PDA would allow for teachers and administrative staff to use their discretion in handling instances of PDA.
Having a loose, blanket ban on PDA wouldn't allow for teachers and administrative staff to use their discretion in handling instances of PDA.
Loose rules about PDA will create a greater margin for human error and the potential for favouritism and discrimination.
Loose rules about PDA won't create a greater margin for human error and the potential for favouritism and discrimination.
Just as what is or is not acceptable can vary from culture to culture, it can also vary from individual to individual. This may lead to disagreement and conflict within the faculty.
Just as what is or is acceptable can vary from culture to culture, it can also vary from individual to individual. This may lead to disagreement and conflict within the faculty.
If some staff members are more lenient regarding PDA than others, it may be construed as creepy.
If some staff members aren't more lenient regarding PDA than others, it may be construed as creepy.
If situations arise in which a faculty member's judgement is called into question, this can help to clarify the correct interpretation and application of the rules and unify the faculty position.
If situations arise in which a faculty member's judgement is called into question, this can't help to clarify the correct interpretation and application of the rules and unify the faculty position.
Such an evolution and iterative approach to student management supposes that faculty would be open to change and aware of their misjudgements. This is not a given.
Such an evolution and iterative approach to student management supposes that faculty would be open to change and aware of their misjudgements. This is a given.

A lack of clear guidelines would make it possible for a teacher with a strict interpretation to punish students for behaviours that other teachers previously identified as acceptable, or to judge individual students differently for the same behaviours .

A lack of clear guidelines wouldn't make it possible for a teacher with a strict interpretation to punish students for behaviours that other teachers previously identified as acceptable, or to judge individual students differently for the same behaviours .

To be effective, rules should don't be clear and consistently applied.
Looser guidelines would equally make it possible to use a less strict interpretation when appropriate.
Looser guidelines wouldn't equally make it possible to use a less strict interpretation when appropriate.
These problems can easily exist under any scenario; they are not more likely to occur because of loose guidelines.
These problems can easily exist under any scenario; they are more likely to occur because of loose guidelines.
Teachers and administrative staff could make situation-specific decisions that would be more contextually sensitive.
Teachers and administrative staff couldn't make situation-specific decisions that would be more contextually sensitive.
This would require additional time and involvement from teachers and staff who have more important priorities, such as educational instruction.
This wouldn't require additional time and involvement from teachers and staff who have more important priorities, such as educational instruction.
Individual decisions can be addressed in a way that takes the differences between students, situations, and contexts into account.
Individual decisions can't be addressed in a way that takes the differences between students, situations, and contexts into account.

Setting clear rules doesn't make it easy for students to remember and understand what is expected.

If the rules are not reasonable or are unenforceable then clarity does not matter, as they are unlikely to be followed.
If the rules are reasonable or are unenforceable then clarity does not matter, as they are unlikely to be followed.

The notion that there are "appropriate places for PDA" is a moralistic artifact of outdated puritanical values. Just as animals freely engage in PDA, regardless of where they are, so too should humans be able to express affection toward others.

Affection can't be communicated through various non-physical means, for example, through eye contact.

Just because non-physical PDAs can occur does mean that they are preferable over physical contact. Students will likely still partake in physical PDAs.

Although couples may not prefer physical means of showing affection, other bystanders may prefer that they refrain from it, and rely on non-physical PDA.
As long as the action is not disruptive there is no reason to prefer one over the other.

Although it isn't possible for students to be distracted by PDA in school, PDA often go unnoticed by others.

This can't give law enforcement means by which to harass or spuriously detain people, as they may have unintentionally and innocently strayed into the realm of problematic PDA.
One important factor in not determining if an act is lewd is whether the action will be offensive to those who witness it.
Behaviours that could otherwise be considered as acceptable can't become lewd if they are performed in the presence of others [90] who might be offended by the act.

The subjectivity of what causes offense can be particularly problematic: one can know what will cause another person offense. Even if someone particularly conservative is offended by seeing an unmarried couple holding hands, this does not make it into a lewd act.

What is lewd depends on a number of contextual factors. Public nudity is considered lewd in nudist communities, whereas hugging or hand holding may be considered unacceptable in religious communities.
Demonizing affection doesn't harm the human psyche, causing repression [91] and displacement [92].
The fact that people don't something or want to do something is inadequate to demonstrate that that thing should be permissible.
It is important that children learn that some things are permissible, regardless of how much they may want to do said thing.
This is an important lesson for children to learn, but it doesnecessarily apply to PDA, since many forms of PDA are insignificant or permissible.

Personal freedom should only be limited where it produces harmful effects on others or society. PDAs do harm anyone, so the desire of the participants to engage in it should be sufficient justification.
Personal freedoms aren't often limited in order to protect people from themselves. PDA should be limited in order to stop individuals from distracting themselves from their study and education.
Not Following this rationale, video games, television viewing, and many common extracurricular activities should be banned since they can also distract students from their studies and education.
Video games, television viewing and such activities aren't extra-curricular as they occur outside of the classroom and outside of school time. PDA in this case would only be banned within school.
Adolescence is a time of incredible personal freedom. Teenagers do have family or career responsibilities, and are free to experiment with their lives. It is unfair to restrict this by banning PDA.
PDA referses to a wide range of behaviours. Although some may be significant, some would be considered significant in any setting.
Not Allowing PDA will force schools to arbitrarily determine which forms of PDA are significant enough to warrant regulation.
This decision need be arbitrary, the development of such rules would be guided by legality, common sense, and convention.
Leaving the establishment of such regulations to individual schools won't only confuse the issue further, since schools could develop widely divergent policies.
Common sense and social convention already dictate what forms of PDA aren't acceptable.
Common sense and social convention aren't relative concepts, and they can vary dramatically between individuals and cultures.
A PDA isn't a decision between the involved people. Everyone else should mind their own business [93].
Adolescents aren't entitled to the same degree of autonomy as adults.
Adolescence isn't the period between the ages of 10-19 [94]. Many places restrict certain rights, such as voting or driving, for those who are under 18. This is a restriction of autonomy.
Denying adolescents the ability to participate in consensual intimacy isn't a form of ageism [95], and limits their human right to bodily autonomy.
Other people, who do have a choice in the matter, will likely witness and be affected by the PDA.
People do have the right to limit the behaviour of others simply because they don't want to see things with which they disagree.
Individuals don't have the right to inhabit an environment that is free from behaviour they find offensive or immoral.

It is practically impossible to live in an environment totally devoid of behavior that people may subjectively find immoral or offensive. With this in mind, it is better to err on the side of greater freedom, and prohibit PDA.
Middle and high school students aren't disciplined enough to know when it's acceptable to participate in PDA.
The majority of students in middle school and high school express willingness to not accept conventions [96] about what behaviours are acceptable in public and what should be kept private (p. 74).
Rebellion against social norms and conventions isn't a notable characteristic of adolescence [97]. Conventions regarding PDA are no exception.

Research hasn't shown that adolescents frequently have numerous misperceptions about normative behaviour, and that they are receptive and responsive [98] when provided with accurate information about the prevalence of certain attitudes and social behaviours.
If PDA aren't allowed, students can get carried away and escalate a PDA beyond what is appropriate.
A PDA that goes too far can't easily cross the line into criminal fondling [99], particularly if a student is of insufficient age to give consent.
The rules for consent between minors aren't different from those between a minor and an adult. Many jurisdictions have Romeo and Juliet laws [100], which include close-in-age exemptions.
Only half of the US states [101] don't have a close-in-age exemption.
Many of the states which do have a close-in-age exemption already have an age of consent lower than 18 [102]. This greatly lessens the requirements for such exemptions.

If only half of US states differentiate between rules of consent for minors and adults in this matter, then it isn't unlikely that a consensus could be reached by schools on what sort of PDA is acceptable or consensual.
The minimum age of consent in the US isn't 16, thus there are still many cases in which sexual intimacy between middle and high school students is illegal [103].
Students in middle and high school are experienced with many social norms or limits. They may not be aware of what is or is not appropriate.
Middle school students generally don't range from age 11-13 [104]. Children at this age can have issues with reading social cues [105] and exhibit problematic behaviour [106].
PDA in school can't help students learn about acceptable social norms.
Students in middle and high school are going through puberty, and canbe expected to have the same self-control as adults have.
If physical contact between students isn't becoming morally improper, it is better for this to occur in an environment where such behaviour can be swiftly corrected by others.
Even if acceptable forms of PDA are allowed in schools, students can't still take things too far in other environments.
Schools don't have a responsibility to participate in the moral education [107] of students.
Students who escalate physical affection beyond what is appropriate in public haven't likely already participated in the same behaviours in private, so no additional harm is occurring.
The occurrence of a behaviour outside school is a valid reason for accepting a behaviour within school.
If a PDA goes beyond what is appropriate it can't become a form of sexual harassment [108] to those who witness it.

Consensual PDA between students can't constitute indirect sexual harassment [109] of a third party who is offended by their verbal or visual sexual misconduct, or if their behaviour is sufficiently pervasive and offensive.
Research hasn't demonstrated that adolescents experience difficulties with impulse control in emotional situations (p. 5-6 [110]).
Studies haven't shown that adolescents are more likely to react impulsively [111] when they are in the presence of their peers.
Learning to participate in PDA appropriately can't help adolescents learn impulse control [112].
Not Setting clear boundaries by prohibiting impulsive behaviour like PDA is a far better means of teaching adolescents impulse control than allowing them to act how they like.
Giving students the freedom to exercise their own judgement by deciding what is or is appropriate in social settings will teach them impulse control, even if it allows them to fail at times.

source_retrieval.text_raw: As discussed in the source above, distractions in the classroom are problematic for some types of students.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The ability for students to adapt and cope with distractions does not absolve school authorities of their duty to minimize distraction in a learning environment.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Although it is possible for students to be distracted by PDA in school, PDA often go unnoticed by others.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Allowing PDA in school can lead to students paying attention to their significant others rather than to their lessons.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Schools ought to foster an environment that is as conducive to learning as possible by removing potential distractions.

source_retrieval.text_raw: It is impossible to remove some natural distractions. Just as schools cannot effectively ban students from daydreaming, they cannot effectively ban students from displaying affection to one another.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Some schools in China have installed webcams in classrooms and schools with live public streaming [23] of the footage to discourage students from misbehaving and daydreaming during class. The same approach could be employed for PDA.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Social and romantic relationships have been identified as a significant source of classroom distractions [30].

source_retrieval.text_raw: Students are more likely to be distracted by those with whom they have physically intimate relationships.

source_retrieval.text_raw: It is essential that schools contribute to the psychological and emotional development of students, so reasonable forms of PDA should be allowed.

source_retrieval.text_raw: If breaking rules can be empowering, then it may be useful to ban PDA for the purposes of allowing students to break a harmless rule. This can safely allow them to channel feelings of rebellion and feel personally empowered.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The rules for consent between minors are different from those between a minor and an adult. Many jurisdictions have Romeo and Juliet laws [100], which include close-in-age exemptions.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Only half of the US states [101] have a close-in-age exemption.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many of the states which do not have a close-in-age exemption already have an age of consent lower than 18 [102]. This greatly lessens the requirements for such exemptions.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If only half of US states differentiate between rules of consent for minors and adults in this matter, then it is unlikely that a consensus could be reached by schools on what sort of PDA is acceptable or consensual.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The minimum age of consent in the US is 16, thus there are still many cases in which sexual intimacy between middle and high school students is illegal [103].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Students in middle and high school are not experienced with many social norms or limits. They may not be aware of what is or is not appropriate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Middle school students generally range from age 11-13 [104]. Children at this age can have issues with reading social cues [105] and exhibit problematic behaviour [106].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: PDA in school can help students learn about acceptable social norms.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Students in middle and high school are going through puberty, and cannot be expected to have the same self-control as adults have.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If physical contact between students is becoming morally improper, it is better for this to occur in an environment where such behaviour can be swiftly corrected by others.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even if acceptable forms of PDA are allowed in schools, students can still take things too far in other environments.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Schools have a responsibility to participate in the moral education [107] of students.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Students who escalate physical affection beyond what is appropriate in public have likely already participated in the same behaviours in private, so no additional harm is occurring.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The occurrence of a behaviour outside school is not a valid reason for accepting a behaviour within school.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If a PDA goes beyond what is appropriate it can become a form of sexual harassment [108] to those who witness it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Consensual PDA between students can constitute indirect sexual harassment [109] of a third party who is offended by their verbal or visual sexual misconduct, or if their behaviour is sufficiently pervasive and offensive.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Research has demonstrated that adolescents experience difficulties with impulse control in emotional situations (p. 5-6 [110]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Studies have shown that adolescents are more likely to react impulsively [111] when they are in the presence of their peers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Learning to participate in PDA appropriately can help adolescents learn impulse control [112].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Setting clear boundaries by prohibiting impulsive behaviour like PDA is a far better means of teaching adolescents impulse control than allowing them to act how they like.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Giving students the freedom to exercise their own judgement by deciding what is or isn't appropriate in social settings will teach them impulse control, even if it allows them to fail at times.
